intro: Malva parviflora subvar. dasycarpa, commonly known as the woolly mallow, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the Mediterranean region. It features heart-shaped leaves with a soft, fuzzy texture, and produces showy pink to purple flowers with five petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, and its stems are covered in fine, woolly hairs. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often found in rocky or coastal areas. The subvariety dasycarpa is distinguished by its densely hairy stems and leaves, contributing to its unique appearance.
